Although Gandhi is a well-known leader, Bhagat has gained more popularity among the Indian populace, particularly younger generations, laborers, and farmers.

Both Bhagat and Jatin Das participated in a 116-day hunger strike for improving the conditions of Indian political prisoners. During this time, Jatin Das contracted cholera in police custody and unfortunately passed away due to its severity.
Both Bhagat and Sukhdev undertook a 116-day hunger strike for improving the conditions of Indian political prisoners.
Both Bhagat and Rajguru undertook a 116-day hunger strike for improving the conditions of Indian political prisoners.

Lord Irwin refused Gandhi's request for releasing Bhagat, Sukhdev, and Rajguru. This was in contrast to the pact signed by both of them, which included the release of political prisoners except for those involved in violence.
All three were hanged in secrecy on 23rd March 1931, even before their trial on 24th March 1931.

Inspired by Udham Singh, film director Rajkumar Santoshi read several books on Bhagat Singh in 1998 and felt that a biopic would help revive interest in him. Although Manoj Kumar made a film about Bhagat in 1965 titled Shaheed, Santoshi felt that despite being 'a great source of inspiration on the lyrics and music front', it did not 'dwell on Bhagat Singh’s ideology and vision'.

In August 2000, screenwriter Anjum Rajabali mentioned to Santoshi about his work on Har Dayal, whose revolutionary activities inspired Udham Singh. Santoshi then persuaded Rajabali to draft a script based on Bhagat’s life as he was inspired by Udham Singh.
Santoshi gave Rajabali a copy of Shaheed Bhagat Singh, K. K. Khullar’s biography of the revolutionary.
Rajabali's interest in Bhagat intensified after he read The Martyr: Bhagat Singh’s Experiments in Revolution (2000) by journalist Kuldip Nayar.

Gurpal Singh, a Film and Television Institute of India graduate, and internet blogger Sagar Pandya assisted Rajabali in his research on Bhagat. Santoshi received input from Kultar Singh, Bhagat’s younger brother, who told the director he would have his full co-operation if the film accurately depicted Bhagat’s ideologies.
Rajabali wanted to 'recreate the world that Bhagat Singh lived in', and his research required him to 'not only understand the man, but also the influences on him, the politics of that era'.
Rajabali said that the film would 'deal with Bhagat Singh, the man, rather than the freedom fighter'

node_1: piyush mishra's 1994 play gagan damama bajyo
edge: Many aspects of Bhagat's life, including his relationship with fiancée Mannewali, were derived from Piyush Mishra's 1994 play Gagan Damama Bajyo; Mishra was subsequently credited with writing the film's dialogues.

These gave Rajabali 'an idea of what had appealed to the man, the literary and intellectual influences that impacted him in that period'

Cast as Bhagat in The Legend of Bhagat Singh because Santoshi felt he had 'the eyes of a revolutionary' and his introvert nature conveyed loudly the signals that there is a volcano inside him ready to burst.

Studied all the references Santoshi and Rajabali had procured to develop the film's script, lost weight to more closely resemble Bhagat Singh, and called The Legend of Bhagat Singh 'the most challenging assignment' in his career as he had not watched Shaheed before signing up for the project.

The scenes at the Bagh set and other surrounding locations of Amritsar at the beginning of the film feature Nakshdeep Singh as the younger Bhagat.
Santoshi selected Nakshdeep after receiving photographs of the boy from his father, Komal Singh.

Kultar stayed with the production unit for seven days during the outdoor location shooting in Pune. Both Santoshi and Devgn appreciated the interactions they had with Kultar, noting that he provided "deep insights into his brother's life".
Kultar was pleased with the sincerity of the cast and crew and shared private letters written by Bhagat with them.
The Legend of Bhagat Singh was made on a budget of ₹200 – 250 million (about US$4.15 – 5.18 million in 2002).
A. R. Rahman composed the soundtrack and score for The Legend of Bhagat Singh.
Santoshi wanted A. R. Rahman to compose songs that would stand apart from his other projects like Lagaan (2001) and Zubeidaa (2001).
Rahman took care to compose the tunes for "Mera Rang De Basanti" in a slow-paced manner to avoid comparisons with the songs in Shaheed, which he and Santoshi found to be fast-paced.

Rahman followed the same procedure for "Sarfaroshi Ki Tamanna". He created a softer tune, saying that the "song is pictured on men who have fasted for over a month. How can I compose a high-sounding tune for that song?"
Despite this, Rahman admitted that "Des Mere Des" had "some strains" from Lagaan's music.
Rahman took "Santoshi's commitment to the film" as a source of inspiration to make an album that was "flavorsome [sic] and different"
Rahman experimented with Punjabi music more than he had done before on his previous soundtracks, receiving assistance from Sukhwinder Singh and Sonu Nigam.

In a comparative analysis, Ziya-Us-Salam found The Legend of Bhagat Singh to be a better film because of the 'clearly etched out' supporting characters and Devgn's more 'restrained and credible' performance compared to Bobby Deol in 23rd March 1931: Shaheed.
Ziya-Us-Salam admired Sushant's performance in The Legend of Bhagat Singh, saying he has 'a fine screen presence, good timing and an ability to hold his own in front of more celebrated actors.'
Salam and Diwanji found Devgn's performance in The Legend of Bhagat Singh to be more 'restrained and credible' compared to Bobby Deol in 23rd March 1931: Shaheed.
Diwanji found The Legend of Bhagat Singh to be the better film in a comparison with 23rd March 1931: Shaheed, despite criticising the 'constant shouting and mouthing of dialogues'.
Diwanji criticised the inclusion of Bhagat's fiancée in The Legend of Bhagat Singh, saying it took liberties with a 'slim' piece of information just to have a girl sing.

Diwanji commended the narrative structure of The Legend of Bhagat Singh, saying it captured the revolutionary's life and journey well, thereby making it 'worth watching' with relevant historical background.
